data.title: Where to Stay in Singapore â€“ Our Favorite Areas & Hotels
data.meta_description: The ultimate guide on where to stay in Singapore. Discover Singapore's best areas & hotels, and quickly find the perfect hotel for your trip.
data.text:
Are you traveling to Singapore and wondering where to stay? Then look no further; here, we give you the ultimate guide on where to stay in Singapore. It includes accommodation guides to Singaporeâ€™s most popular neighborhoods and our favorite hotel picks at all price ranges.

If youâ€™re flying into Singapore straight from the US or Europe, it may at first feel like you have not traveled very far at all. On the surface, it is perhaps the most â€œnon-Asianâ€ of all Asian countries. The radio hosts speak English, the cab driver will insist that you wear your seatbelt, and prices are just as high as back home.

But dig a little beneath the surface, and Singapore will reveal its charm, diversity, and ethnic roots. Even though the island city-state of Singapore is quite small, it has many unique neighborhoods and a well of accommodations. Therefore, deciding where to stay in Singapore can feel a bit overwhelming.

It is almost like you are visiting several different countries and cultures just by walking between the different neighborhoods of Singapore. From the lively and colorful Little India to the charming hipster-like Kampong Glam, to the enormous shopping malls along Orchard Road, the impressively posh and futuristic Marina Bay, the bustling nightlife of the Quays, the beautiful colonial buildings of the Colonial District, and the kid-friendly entertainment and beach hub Sentosa Island with Universal Studios.

We first visited Singapore many years ago after finishing our studies in Australia as a stopover on the way to Norway. We immediately fell in love with this exciting city. We try to visit Singapore every time we are in Asia, which means almost every year, and we have stayed in many different hotels all over the city and at different price ranges.

For a while now, we have wanted to write more articles about Singapore. However, things can change fast, and we did not want to rely on past experiences. So, we booked a flight and spent a month in Singapore exploring the city like never before.

One of the results is this guide on where to stay in Singapore with all the little hotel gems we could find. Here we reveal what we think are the best areas to stay in Singapore and why. We have listed our favorite hotels at any budget for each area â€“ Top-End, Mid-Range, and Budget.

Latest Updates: We last visited Singapore in February 2024 to thoroughly update this guide to Singaporeâ€™s best hotels and areas. We wanted to see if our old hotel favorites were still going strong, and along the way, we also discovered some new favorites that we are excited to share with you! We have also added Katong, a new upcoming area that is quickly becoming popular with visitors.

Where To Stay In Singapore

Whether you are looking for that once-in-a-lifetime luxury hotel, a small, intimate boutique hotel, a value-for-money mid-range hotel, or a budget guesthouse, Singapore has it all.

You must be warned, though, that Singapore is among the most expensive cities in Asia. Singapore has been dubbed the worldâ€™s most expensive city to live in for the fifth year in a row, which is also reflected in the hotel prices. However, in this guide, we will also reveal some good value options for your money, so there is no need to panic. ðŸ™‚

Singapore is also the only major city where we have experienced landing at the airport, only to be told that the cityâ€™s hotels are all fully occupied and no rooms are available anywhere! Thankfully, it turned out to be a slight exaggeration, but there was a huge dentist conference in town, and every major hotel was full. We managed to find a place to stay in the end, but we had to pay far more than we had budgeted, and ever since then, we have always booked ahead when visiting Singapore.

The hotels recommended in this article are primarily places we have stayed at ourselves. However, to make this as complete and helpful a resource as possible, we have included some recommendations from travelers we know personally and whose opinions we trust.

Important: None of the hotels in this guide are paid placements or have sponsored our stay in any way. We have paid for these accommodations ourselves. If you book through any of our links, we earn a small commission at no extra cost to you. This helps keep our site going â€“ so thank you in advance for your support! â™¥

We hope you find this guide helpful in choosing the best place to stay in Singapore.

Singaporeâ€™s 9 Best Areas To Stay In

Although Singapore is rather small, 728.6 kmÂ², it has almost 6 million inhabitants from all over the world. The different neighborhoods have their own character, which reflects their people and culture in a unique way.

Where you base yourself matters, both when it comes to whether or not the attractions are within walking distance and if you have many different restaurants, cafes, and shops to choose from. That said, Singapore is a fairly easy city to get around in, both by taxi/ Grab and public transport like the metro and buses.

We have decided to divide Singapore into nine areas that are suitable for tourists and visitors to stay in.

Here is an overview of Singapore`s nine most popular areas to stay in (updated in 2024):

Orchard Road Area

Singaporeâ€™s main shopping area. The whole street is lined with huge modern shopping malls. The most central area to stay in, you can walk to most of the main attractions. Several of the big international hotel chains are located here.

Colonial/ Historic District

Beautiful old colonial buildings, museums, and art galleries. Here, you will find some of Singaporeâ€™s most iconic and luxurious hotels, like the Raffles.

Marina Bay Area

The iconic Marina Bay Sands shopping mall and hotel are designed like a ship. Staying at the futuristic luxurious Marina Bay Sands Hotel is a once-in-a-lifetime experience, so if you can afford it â€“ go for it!

Chinatown

A unique historical area with a mix of Chinese architecture, temples, shops, cafes, and modern highrises in the nearby CBD. A wide range of upscale and mid-range hotels.

Bugis & Kampong Glam

Singaporeâ€™s hippest area has plenty of cool coffee shops, cafes, restaurants, and pubs. Budget-friendly hotels and hostels are also available.

The Quays Area

Singaporeâ€™s canal and river area is nightlife central, packed with restaurants, cafes, and bars. It is a fun area to stay in, with some fantastic hotels and nightlife.

Little India

A vibrant area with lots of delicious Indian food. Budget-friendly hotels and hostels.

Sentosa Island

This kid-friendly area includes Universal Studios, the Singapore Aquarium, and a string of relaxing beaches. Sentosa offers a mix of large resort hotels and smaller elegant boutique hotels at a price.

Katong

Beautiful old shophouse architecture, a residential feel with cozy cafes and eateries, a seaside park, excellent hotels, and a brand-new MRT line makes Katong an up and coning area with visitors.

Read on to find out where you want to stay when visiting Singapore. We have also listed our favorite hotels in each area below:

The 9 best areas to stay in Singapore: 1. Orchard Road, 2. Colonial/ Historic, 3. Marina Bay, 4. The Quays, 5. Bugis & Kampong Glam, 6. Chinatown, 7. Little India, 8. Sentosa Island, 9. Katong

1. Orchard Road

Orchard Road is home to what is arguably the worldâ€™s best upscale shopping district. Along the wide Orchard Road (2,5 km long), enormous modern shopping malls line both sides of the street. If you canâ€™t find what you are looking for here, chances are you will not find it anywhere in the world.

Why stay in the Orchard Road area?

To sum it up in one word â€“ shopping! Most visitors stay in the Orchard Road area for the shopping! From luxury fashion clothing brands to electronic and camera shops, Orchard is a shopperâ€™s dream destination.

But there is more to Orchard than just shopping. Venture into the smaller side streets, and you will discover plenty of cool bars, restaurants, and a more relaxed atmosphere. We love walking along Emerald Hill Road with its beautiful, well-preserved heritage buildings.

Inside the shopping malls, youâ€™ll find cinema multiplexes and plenty of restaurants, food courts, and cafes for that shopping break. Food courts are a particularly good value for money in a city famous for its high prices.

If you are a book lover like us, do not miss a visit to the Singapore branch of the Kinokuniya Book Store inside the Ngee Ann City Mall (on level 4). It is the worldâ€™s largest bookstore, and we have spent more hours than I care to admit digging for book treasures there.

Just north of Orchard Road, you can escape the cityÂ´s hustle and bustle in the green lung Istana Park, where you will also find the Presidentâ€™s Residence.

MRT lines connect the area well, and you are never far from the nearest station, making it easy to get around the rest of the city from here. There are currently four major MRT stations in the Orchard Road area: Orchard, Orchard Boulevard, Somerset, and Dhoby Ghaut MRT stations.

Things to see and do in the Orchard Road area

Shopping, shopping, and some more shopping, as well as eating, are the main things to do in the Orchard Road area. It indeed is a shopping mecca! Orchard Road is one of the best shopping streets in Asia, maybe the best.

Cathay Gallery

Cathay Gallery is the perfect museum for us film nerds! Here you find cool old movie posters, local Singapore film history, and cameras.

Istana Park

A lovely little landscaped park of 13 kmÂ² that opened in 1996. Istana Parkâ€™s centerpiece is the Festival Arch (26 m tall), surrounded by a reflecting pool. The arch symbolizes the gateway to Orchard Road.

Istana Heritage Gallery

Inside the park, the Istana Heritage Gallery (opened in 2017) showcases the history of Istanaâ€™s transition from being the Colonial Governorâ€™s House to its present role as the Presidentâ€™s Official Residence. Here, you can see a range of heritage displays with state artifacts, artworks, and a collection of gifts presented by foreign countries to Singaporeâ€™s Presidents and Prime Ministers.

ION Orchard Mall

SingaporeÂ´s top-notch mega mall. Check out its observation deck, ION Sky, on level 56, with an amazing view over the city.

Eat At Food Courts

Check out the many food courts in the Orchard Road area. Almost all the malls have one selling cheap, freshly cooked food from around the world. Our favorite food courts in Orchard are:

â€“ Takashimaya Food Village â€“ At B2 in Takashimaya Department Store

â€“ Food Republic â€“ At level 4 in Wisma Atria

â€“ Food Opera â€“ At level B4 in ION Orchard Mall

Singapore Botanic Gardens

Singapore Botanic Gardens is the worldâ€™s only tropical garden declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is free to visit (with some exceptions) and is open daily from 05:00 a.m. until midnight. Our favorite part of the garden is the National Orchid Garden (last entry at 18:00/ 6 pm, ticket: 15 SG$).

Emerald Hill Road

Go for a walk and admire these beautiful heritage architectural buildings. Some popular and cozy bars are also in the old renovated shophouses near Orchard Road.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

Orchard Road gets busy, particularly on the weekends and holidays, and while there are plenty of cinemas, the nightlife is a little limited.

The hotel prices here are on the higher end, and there are very few hostels and cheap hotels for budget travelers.

Where To Stay Around Orchard Road

There are plenty of quality hotels around Orchard including from the top international hotel chains. Some of our favorites include:

Top End

Four Seasons Hotel

The Four Seasons Hotel has been one of Singaporeâ€™s classic five-star hotels for thirty years, but since completing its refurbishment a few years back, itâ€™s looking better than ever. It has everything a top-notch five-star hotel should have: great service, excellent food (two restaurants and a lobby bar), beautiful rooms, a well-equipped gym, and a stunning rooftop swimming pool on the 20th floor. There are even two outdoor tennis courts!

The Four Seasons is centrally located on Orchard Road, in the middle of everything. Staying here, youâ€™re within easy walking distance of all the shopping, cinemas, cafes, and restaurants. You can easily access the MRT/ trains to get around the rest of Singapore. It is by far one of the best and most luxurious hotels in Singapore.

Click for latest prices

Goodwood Park Hotel

The Goodwood Park Hotel is one of Singaporeâ€™s grand old heritage hotels with a lot of history. Walking onto the grand grounds, we felt we were stepping back in time. Although the hotel is newly renovated, they have kept the old and grand vibe and decor.

The building dates back to 1900 and was built as the headquarters for The German Gentlemenâ€™s Club. Everything from the lobby to the restaurant and the room design is super elegant and classy! The hotel oozes old-world colonial charm, from the lush landscaped garden, marble tiles, and colonial architecture to the wide stairways.

The hotel has only three floors with a mix of modern and heritage rooms. We stayed in Heritage Room no. 4 on the 2nd floor, which was spacious (31 sqm) and designed with warm, elegant colors in a classic style. The bed was super comfortable.

Maria enjoyed soaking in the classic bathtub and the small luxuries like toiletries by Salvatore Ferragamo. On the downside, the bathroom did not have a separate shower, meaning you must stand in the tub when showering.

We were also a bit unlucky, as some teenagers had booked the neighboring room and were throwing a birthday party. These old buildings donâ€™t exactly have the best soundproofing, so if youâ€™re a light sleeper, this is something to consider.

We loved the swimming pool on the ground floor, set in a green and lush garden with plenty of sunbeds, perfect for relaxation. The hotel also has studio apartments with a kitchen available. The hotelâ€™s Lâ€™Espresso Cafe serves a popular English-style afternoon tea buffet from 11 until 19, which is worth checking out even if you are not staying there. The Goodwood Park Hotel has a great location, and Orchard Road is just a 5-minute walk away.

Click for latest prices

Artyzen Singapore

The new kid on the block is the five-star Artyzen Hotel (which opened in late 2023)! Weâ€™ve watched the highrise slowly take shape during the building process, and the towerâ€™s unique design, with its many stacked gardens spiraling upwards, is striking!

The hotel is built on the former site of Villa Marie, an old heritage mansion built in the 1940s. The new hotelâ€™s design (by Singapore architects ONG&ONG) is inspired by the old villa. They had the idea of stacking multiple villas on top of each other, each with its own lush green garden. This unique design gives guests easy access to lush green gardens throughout the hotel.

Art adores every corner of the hotel, from the artwork in the lobby to the elevatorâ€™s backdrop depicting Singaporeâ€™s historic shophouses. The rooms are beautifully designed with eye-catching artwork, including headboards embroidered with motives from Singaporeâ€™s Peranakan legacy.

The spacious rooms, starting at 48 sqm, have high arched ceilings and floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the city. Modern hotel comforts include a huge 55-inch flat-screen TV, a Nespresso coffee machine, a fully stocked minibar, 24-hour room service, and a balcony.

The luxurious bathrooms have a rainforest shower with Heeley Paris shower products and a grand bathtub. If you opt for a Terrace Suite, youâ€™ll even have your private tropical garden!

On the fifth floor is the wellness area. It includes a 24/7 fitness center, a luxurious spa, and daily guided meditation and yoga classes. Take the elevator up to the top floor, and youâ€™ll find the rooftop terrace garden. Enjoy a drink or a snack at the bar, relax on one of the many sunbeds, or swim in the 25-meter-long infinity pool with spectacular views.

The hotel is on the quiet Cuscaden Road, within walking distance of Orchard Road and the Botanical Gardens. A complimentary chauffeur service will drive you anywhere within a mile of the hotel.

Click For Latest Prices

Shangri-La Hotel

The luxurious Shangri-La Hotel is located at the west end of Orchard Road, right in the middle of all the amazing shopping opportunities Singapore offers.

What sets the Shangri-La Hotel apart is that the hotel grounds and garden cover an incredible six hectares of tropical gardens in the middle of the city! Inside this green oasis, youâ€™ll find a gorgeous swimming pool, a pond with a small waterfall, orchids galore, and plenty of palm trees.

The hotel has three distinctly different wings from which to choose. Staying in one of the rooms in the bungalow villa-styled oasis Garden Wing is like staying at a resort. The Tower Wing has newly renovated rooms, each with a unique theme. The exclusive Valley Wing is for those who want the most exclusive, private stay possible. The American president chose to stay at Shangri-La during the summit with North Koreaâ€™s leader in 2018.

Click for latest prices

Mid Range

JEN Singapore Orchardgateway by Shangri-La

Oh boy, what an infinity swimming pool the JEN Singapore Orchardgateway Hotel has! It must be one of the best in Singapore! It is huge and located on the rooftop with an excellent view of Singaporeâ€™s skyline. And it is open until 23:00, so itâ€™s the perfect place to enjoy a drink or a swim under the stars. We â™¥ it!

There are no less than three pools, including a childrenâ€™s pool! And unlike most hotels weâ€™ve ever stayed at, a lifeguard is on duty.

We had only booked two nights at the JEN Singapore Orchardgateway Hotel, but we liked it so much that we extended our stay. This is one of our favorite hotels in Singapore.

The location of the JEN Singapore Orchardgateway Hotel is perfect! The hotel is located on the upper floors of the Orchard Gateway Mall on Orchard Rd (the reception is on the 10th floor of the mall).

The Orchard Gateway Mall also houses the MRT Somerset Station, which is convenient for getting around Singapore. Just take the hotel elevator down, and you are in the middle of all the restaurants and shops that Orchard Gateway Mall, Orchard Central Mall, and 313 Somerset Mall have to offer (they are all connected).

Behind the hotel is a street called Killiney Rd, with cozy and cheap restaurants serving delicious Indian, Chinese, Vietnamese, and Malaysian food. Itâ€™s great for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

Our room was big, comfortable, modern, and extremely quiet. We could not hear anything from our neighbors or the cleaning staff in the morning. The internet was fast and free. And the hotel even has a robot (!), the cute Jeno, which delivers room service food, etc. We called reception and asked for some water, and Jeno, the robot, came to our rescue. ðŸ™‚

Click for latest prices

Quincy Hotel Singapore by Far East Hospitality

This boutique hotel is a budget-friendly option close to Orchard Road (just a 7-minute walk away) and is located on a quiet side street. We booked a Premier Room, which was spacious (32 sqm) and comfortable, with a great city view (our room was on the 14th floor). I loved relaxing on the sofa by the window and enjoying the view.

The hotel offers plenty of free perks, which makes this hotel a good deal. We especially enjoyed the free drinks (2 glasses of beer, wine, or mocktails each) and delicious canapes between 18/ 6 pm and 20/ 8 pm every evening.

There is also 24-hour lounge access with complimentary light refreshments like tea, coffee, sodas, snacks, and fruits in the cafe by the reception.

The mini-bar is complimentary, and you can choose what items to stock it with from a selection of drinks and snacks!

On check-in, we got free ice cream sandwiches from Sinaporeâ€™s local ice cream brand, The Ice Cream & Cookie Co. We chose Mint Chocolate, which was delicious!

We also highly appreciated the excellent Wi-Fi, which was super fast â€”300/220Mbit! We could stream all the movies and series we wanted.

The 12th floor has a swimming pool, gym, lounge area, and sauna. The pool is, however, shaded under a roof, so it is not ideal for sunbathing. However, there are a few sunbeds next to the pool. On the plus side, the pool is open 24/7, which is awesome!

We found the complimentary breakfast very tasty and loved that we could order it until 3 pm/15:00! This is awesome if you want to sleep in a bit and get over the jetlag. We had breakfast after checking out at 12:00, which was so convenient. I had the avocado toast with smoked salmon and porched eggsâ€”so good!

All in all, Quincy is a great hotel with lots of awesome free perks, great service, and high-class food!

Click for latest prices

2. Colonial / Historic District

Why stay in the Colonial/ Historic area?

This is our favorite area to stay in Singapore as it is very central and has easy access to Singaporeâ€™s other areas. From here, you can easily walk to the bars and restaurants in the Quay area and Marina Bay, enjoy the delicious street food in Bugis & Kampong Glam area or Little India, and get to Orchard Road with all the great shopping.

The area has many beautiful architectural masterpieces and classic buildings and is lovely to explore on foot. Should you tire of the city, Fort Canning Park, one of central Singaporeâ€™s finest parks, is perfect for a run or an afternoon walk among the tall trees.

Singapore has some of the worldâ€™s finest museums and galleries, most of which are located in the colonial area. The iconic National Museum and the National Gallery are located here.

The area has several MRT stations and two lines (from City Hall Station), making traveling throughout the rest of Singapore easy.

Things to see and do in the Colonial/ Historic District

Battle Box at Fort Canning Park

Battle Box is an underground bunker with 30 rooms built inside the hill as a commando central. In 1942, the decision to surrender Singapore to the Japanese was made here. Today, the bunker (formerly the Underground Far East Command Centre) is known as Battle Box. You can join an organized tour of the bunker.

National Museum of Singapore

The National Museum of Singapore is Singaporeâ€™s oldest museum, dating back to 1849 when it was called Raffles Library and Museum. It is housed in a beautiful old colonial-style building, and here you can learn everything about Singapore and its history and culture. They also have special exhibitions and events. We joined a guided tour, and it was great! They run English-guided tours on Monday â€“ Friday at 11:00 am and 14:00 and Saturday â€“ Sunday at 11:00, 14:00, and 15:00.

National Gallery Singapore

The National Gallery Singapore has the largest collection of modern Southeast Asian art in the world. But here you also find the biggest collection of Italian Renaissance paintings (outside of Italy). Including paintings by European masters from the 15th to the 19th century, such as Turner, Leonardo, VelÃ¡zquez, Titian, Constable, Botticelli, Monet, Caravaggio, and Vermeer. The top three most popular paintings at the National Gallery Singapore are van Eyckâ€™s Arnolfini Portrait, Holbeinâ€™s Ambassadors, and Van Goghâ€™s Sunflowers. We also loved the photography exhibitions at the gallery.

Buy your tickets to National Gallery online here, and skip the ticket line.

Fort Canning Park

Fort Canning Park is beautifully situated on a hill and has a fascinating history. Here was once the center of Ancient Singpura (in the 14th century) and housed the palace of the King. Centuries later, this is where the Union Flag was hoisted to mark the signing of The Singapore Treaty with Stamford Raffles and the birth of Singapore. Later, in 1823, Raffles built his residence on the hill. He also established Singaporeâ€™s first botanical garden on the hillside. Later, in 1861, Fort Canning was built on top of the hill to defend the harbor. The fort was, however, a failure and was demolished in 1907. Today, you can see the gateway of the fort and two nine-pound cannons here. By the way, donâ€™t miss visiting the Thiong Bahru bakery located just inside the park!

Raffles Hotel

The stunning British-colonial-style luxury hotel Raffles was first built in 1830 as a beach house. It became a hotel in 1878. The Raffles Hotel underwent a major two-year renovation and reopened in 2019, with all 115 rooms refurbished and soundproofed. Head to Rafflesâ€™s historic Long Bar for its famous Singapore Sling drink.

St Andrewâ€™s Cathedral

The beautiful white Neo-Gothic architectural style of St Andrewâ€™s Cathedral is a centerpiece of the district. It was first built in 1836 before being struck and destroyed by lightning twice (!) in 1852. Todayâ€™s church building was constructed between 1856 and 1861. The church was used as an emergency hospital during World War II, after the fall of Singapore to the Japanese in 1942. Saint Andrewâ€™s Cathedral was declared a Singaporean National Monument in 1973 and is a fantastic sight to visit.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

The central district is not an area with much action; it is quiet, especially in the evening after 22:00. The accommodations here are quite expensive, and there are very few budget or hostel options.

Where To Stay in Singaporeâ€™s Colonial/ Historical District

Top End

Raffles Hotel

Singaporeâ€™s most famous hotel, the iconic Raffles Hotel, is open again after being closed for years for a complete renovation. The beautiful white colonial-era building and the lush green garden have been beautifully restored, and the Raffles Hotel appears again in all its glory.

This is as old-world luxury as you can get, and no other hotel in Singapore can match its historical nostalgia. Here is the Long Bar, where the now world-famous Singapore Sling drink was created in 1915. Legends such as Ernest Hemingway, Charlie Chaplin, and Michael Jackson have all stayed at the Raffles.

The beautifully renovated spacious suites (the smallest is 45 sqm!) have maintained their classic, elegant colonial style with high ceilings, teak wood floors, oriental rugs, balconies, and four-poster beds while adding every modern comfort youâ€™d expect at a modern five-star hotel. The service is world-famous, with a 24-hour butler service that has perfected the art of always being discretely available.

Pamper yourself at the spa, spend a day by the gorgeous tropical garden swimming pool, or treat yourself to Rafflesâ€™s famous Afternoon Tea service served in The Grand Lobby. With eight in-house restaurants, bars, and cafes, there is no shortage of dining options.

Location-wise, youâ€™re right in the cityâ€™s heart, five minutes away from Raffles Mall and the MRT station, and within easy walking distance of all the sights in the Colonial district.

Staying at the Raffles Hotel is by no means cheap, but itâ€™s a true classic, a one-of-a-kind luxury hotel for that once-in-a-lifetime special holiday or celebration!

Click for latest prices

Pullman Singapore Hill Street

Sinagporeâ€™s newest five-star hotel celebrated its grand opening in October 2023 and has received rave reviews ever since. We havenâ€™t had a chance to stay here yet, but itâ€™s definitively on our list for our next Singapore visit! With 350 guest rooms and suites, this is the brandâ€™s new flagship hotel.

The hotelâ€™s design is a nostalgic love letter to Pullmanâ€™s roots as a 19th-century luxury railroad provider. It looks gorgeous, from the stylish lobby with classic artwork to the well-appointed, relaxing guestrooms. Deluxe Room sizes start at 25 sqm, which is on the smaller side for five-stars in Singapore, but if you need extra space, more spacious King rooms are also available.

There are two large swimming pools, but the real standout is the rooftop pool, which has a fantastic view across Singapore Harbour. The gym is open 24/7, modern, and well-equipped, including gear for more functional training.

Singapore landmarks such as Fort Canning Park, St Andrews Cathedral, and the National Gallery surround the hotel, putting you in the heart of the historic colonial district. The City Hall MRT Station is a five-minute walk away, making it easy to explore the city.

Click For Latest Prices

Swissotel The Stamford

The 5-star Swissotel The Stamford is in a perfect location in the heart of central Singapore. It is just next to the Raffles City Market (connected at level 3 of the hotel), which has many shops and eateries. The nearest MRT station is just a few steps from the hotel and has a direct line to Changi Airport.

The hotel is Singaporeâ€™s tallest and one of South East Asiaâ€™s tallest at 226 meters. All 1252 guest rooms have private balconies and breathtaking city and harbor views. On a clear day, you can see all the way to Malaysia and Indonesia from the upper floors!

The hotel underwent a full refurbishment a few years ago, and all guest rooms are now updated and refreshed with modern comfort and thoughtful touches like free Nespresso and TWG tea. Although the hotel is in a busy area, the rooms are soundproofed and quiet.

The hotel has two large circular swimming pools set in a green garden on the sixth floor. There is also a well-equipped fitness center and a staggering six (!) tennis courts.

Even if youâ€™re not staying here, the SKAI restaurant and bar on the 70th floor is worth a visit for its fantastic 360-degree view of Singapore!

Click for latest prices

Mid Range

Citadines Connect City Centre Hotel

The 4-star Citadines Connect Hotel is like a breath of fresh air centrally located in the historic district of Singapore. When it opened its doors in July 2022, we knew we had to check it out on our next Singapore trip.

We booked a Deluxe Queen Room (18 sqm) and got one on the 4th floor. They also have some really cute loft rooms, which are a bit larger. Our room was fresh, new, stylish, compact with a smart layout, and had a cool 60â€™s vibe.

The complimentary minibar with free chips, soda, water, and juice was a nice surprise. The bed was very comfortable, and our room also had a large flat-screen TV, a sofa and table, an ironing board, and slippers, although no robes.

Unfortunately, we checked into the hotel pretty late in the evening, as we arrived by bus from Melaka in Malaysia. We immediately headed up to the rooftop swimming pool where the hotelâ€™s restaurant is located â€“ the Edition Rooftop Bar & Restaurant (open 07:00 â€“ 02 at night). It is such a cozy little restaurant and bar, where Espen had a delicious hamburger, and I had a tasty pasta bolognese and some wine.

The next day, we got to try out the rooftop swimming pool, open from 07 until 21. Itâ€™s a nice place to hang out and relax, with sunbeds and seating groups. There is a small gym next to the pool. Some of the gym equipment (like the rowing machine) is actually in the pool, which they call Aqua Gym! The first time we have seen that in a hotel.

The cozy cafe downstairs serves a fusion of European and Japanese food (open 08:30 â€“ 17:30). We did not get to try it out as we walked over to the Tiong Bahru Bakery in the neighboring Fort Canning Park to grab some lunch instead.

The hotel is conveniently located next to Fort Canning Park, with Dhoby Ghaut MRT Station just across the road (a 3-minute walk, exit B). The National Museum is just a 10-minute walk from the hotel, and you can easily walk to the shopping malls on Orchard Road in 10 minutes or so.

This hotel is a great choice if you want to do our recommended Singapore itinerary. The starting point of Day 1 of the itinerary (Singapore breakfast at Killiney Kopitiam) is just a 9-minute walk from Citadines Connect City Centre Hotel. This is one of the cheapest hotels in this central area of Singapore and is such a great value.

Click here for the latest prices

Rendezvous Hotel Singapore by Far East Hospitality

With an excellent location just opposite the road from the Bencoolen MRT Station and on a side street from the National Museum of Singapore, the Rendezvous Hotel was a positive surprise for us. Although the Rendezvous Hotel is not the newest in town, it was completely refurbished in 2018. We think it offers good value in a central and otherwise expensive location.

We stayed here for three nights and found the hotel very conveniently located. It is within walking distance of the shopping on Orchard Road.

Our favorite was the hotelâ€™s swimming pool in the lovely little garden on the 3rd floor. We loved chilling out here after shopping in Orchard Road. There is also a gym on the same floor.

We stayed in a Superior Double Room, which was spacious (26 sqm) and clean. Although the interior design of our room was not the most modern, it had its cozy charm, and we had a modern Samsung TV.

There are some restaurants and cafes, including a 7-Eleven in the hotelâ€™s basement and a Foodrepublic food court with lots of excellent and cheap food just opposite the road. We had lunch there several times, and the food was delicious. It is easy to get to the Rendezvous Hotel from Changi Airport by bus no. 36, which stops right outside the hotel.

Click for the latest prices

3. Marina Bay

If you continue east along the river from the Quay area, you will get to the booming, modern, futuristic Marina Bay.

If you donÂ´t plan to stay in this area, visiting here is a must! Make sure to be at Gardens by the Bay at 19:45 or 20:45 when the Supertrees glow and perform a spectacular light and music show. Also, the 15-minute light and music show in front of the Marina Bay Sands is amazing! It is played every evening at 20:00 and 21:00. On Fridays and Saturdays, there is an extra show at 22:00.

Why stay in the Marina Bay area?

The hotels in this area have a great view of the bay and the city. You will find some of Singaporeâ€™s biggest and most luxurious hotels in Marina Bay. It is a beautiful area overlooking the harbor. This area is quite central, and you can easily walk to many of Singaporeâ€™s top attractions.

Things to see and do in Marina Bay

As you go for a stroll around the harbor area of Marina Bay, you will notice this white statue spitting water. 4. Chinatown & Central Business District (CBD)

Chinatown lies in the shadow of the ever-expanding Central Business District (CBD) with its tall skyscrapers packed with offices. The houses in Chinatown are much lower, more like three to four stories tall, and many have been beautifully preserved.

Although Chinatown has some beautiful temples, it lacks world famous attractions and sights. However, in our opinion, the neighborhoodâ€™s atmosphere and delicious food are enough reasons to stay and visit this area of Singapore. You can find everything from cheap hawker food to top-notch fancy restaurants serving food from all over the world.

Why stay in the Chinatown area?

If you stay in Chinatown, youâ€™ll be in the middle of the action. Wander the streets and admire the beautiful temples, historic Peranakan-style shophouses, and gorgeous street art. Youâ€™re rarely far from one of Chinatownâ€™s many fantastic eateries. As night sets, head to Ann Siang Rd and Club Street, filled with bars, restaurants, and great nightlife.

Chinatown is one of Singaporeâ€™s most atmospheric areas, with its old Chinese medicine shops, markets, and hawker food centers.

Regarding accommodation, Chinatown has many options, from high-priced, top-end boutique hotels to budget hostels. It is the perfect place to stay for backpackers seeking cheap accommodation, business travelers working in the nearby Central Business District (CBD), and those who want to see the cultural sights and explore the roots of Singapore.

Several MRT stations (Chinatown Station, Telok Ayer Station, Outram Park Station, Tanjong Pagar Station, and Raffles Place Station) make this area a great place to stay for quickly getting around the city.

The Chinatown street market is set along Pagoda Street, Trengganu Street, Sago Lane, Smith Street, and Temple Street. It is mostly a day market, and most stalls close around 20/ 8 pm. Here, you can find souvenirs, clothes, and some handicrafts.

The Chinatown Heritage Centre is a lovely museum that explains the history and culture of Chinatown using old photos and the personal stories of the families that used to live there.

Buddha Tooth Relic Temple

The Buddha Tooth Relic Temple was completed in 2007 and houses what is claimed to be Buddhaâ€™s tooth relic. The tooth is 7,5 cm long, so way too long for any human. You can view the tooth on the 4th floor of the temple. The temple is huge and consists of four stories. You will find a theatre and a dining hall in the basement (vegetarian meals only, which are free, but a donation is welcome).

Thian Hock Keng Temple & Mural Street Art

Thian Hock Keng Taoist Temple is Singaporeâ€™s oldest Chinese temple, built in 1839. It is stunning and a grand example of traditional Southern Chinese architecture. We love the templesâ€™ small details, the beautiful carvings, and statues of dragons, deities, phoenixes, and other creatures. The temple has been declared a Singaporean National Monument.

Also, you cannot avoid noticing the fantastic 44-meter-long mural on the outside rear wall of the Thian Hock Keng Temple. It was made by the Singaporean artist Yip Yew Chong and tells the story of Singaporeâ€™s early Hokkien immigrants.

Sri Mariamman Hindu Temple

The Sri Mariamman Hindu Temple was founded in 1827 by the government clerk Naraina Pillai from Penang. He first arrived in Singapore with Sir Stamford Raffles (the founder of Singapore) and started Singaporeâ€™s first construction company and textile trading. He quickly became the leader of Singaporeâ€™s Indian community. The temple is so colorful and full of details. It is declared a Singaporean National Monument.

Singapore City Gallery

At Singapore City Gallery you can learn about Singaporeâ€™s impressive urban development over the last 50 years and the philosophy behind creating this modern and futuristic city. The gallery also shows future plans for Singapore. We love how they have managed to make the exhibitions interactive and fun. It was also fun getting an overview of the entire city center of Singapore on the scale replica (you find it on the second floor).

Ann Siang Rd and Club Street

The two streets, Ann Siang Road and Club Street, are the perfect place to head for dinner and a drink at a rooftop bar. The streets are lined with beautifully restored old Chinese shophouses, which now house restaurants, cafes, shops, fitness studios, and bars. Here, you will find some of the best restaurants and bars in Singapore.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

It can be a crowded and noisy area, especially in the evenings and weekends when many tourists head to Chinatown for the nightlife.

6. The Quays â€“ Clarke Quay, Robertson Quay & Boat Quay

Connected by the Singapore River and occupying roughly the area in between the old Colonial District and the Central Business District are the three Quays of Singapore:

Clark Quay

Robertson Quay

Boat Quay

Once the heart of commercial trade along the river and an important trading station for ships coming into the harbor, the Quays gradually lost its importance. By the late 80s, the area consisted of old abandoned warehouses.

Today, the area is transformed into an entertainment center with many bars, tourist shops, microbreweries, restaurants, and nightclubs lining the river on both sides, as well as the smaller side streets.

Why Stay In The Quays Area?

The Quays is Singaporeâ€™s nightlife center, so if you want to stay in an area with plenty of dining and late-night partying options, this is an excellent choice. Another tip is to explore the side streets to find the best restaurants.

Marina Bay and Chinatown are both within walking distance of the Quays. The Clarke Quay and Fort Canning Park MRT stations are nearby, making it easy to reach other parts of Singapore.

Things to see and do in The Quays area

Boat Quay

This is the closest area to the old harbor and is declared a conservation area by the government of Singapore. It is packed with upscale bars (a bit touristy), shops, and waterside restaurants.

Clarke Quay

Clarke, the second colonial governor of Singapore, named this harbor area after himself. It is the most popular area on the Quay and has many nice bars, clubs, and restaurants.

Robertson Quay

Storage buildings once dominated this harbor area, but now you will find bars and members-only party places here. It has a more sophisticated and calm vibe than the other two Quays, with more upscale restaurants than party places.

Asian Civilisation Museum

The Asian Civilisation Museum has Asiaâ€™s most comprehensive collection of Asian treasures. It is well worth a visit. They had an exhibition about Angkor in Cambodia when we visited, which was fantastic!

Cavenagh Bridge

This beautiful bridge was made in Scotland and reassembled in Singapore in 1869. It is illuminated at night.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

Itâ€™s fun for an evening out, but the menu-clutching touts continually trying to usher you into their riverside restaurants and the over-the-top colorfully designed nightclubs can get a bit much. You wonâ€™t find that many cultural attractions in this area.

7. Little India

Little India is a lively, vibrant ethnic district north of the Singapore River.

While the area is predominantly Indian, Mosques and churches stand alongside Hindu temples and posters for the latest Bollywood blockbusters.

Head to Serangoon Road to experience Little Indiaâ€™s colorful shops selling textiles, cheap fashions, spices, and bargain electronics. Spice racks on display fill the air with mouth-watering smells, and the eateries along Serangoon Road serve up a mix of Indian, Chinese, and Arabian cousins.

Whether you are looking for a tasty, cheap curry served on a banana leaf South Indian style or an upscale dining experience, Little India rarely disappoints.

In the evenings, the streets fill up, the colorful street light comes on, and Little India becomes a lively place popular with locals and visitors. Little India is as close to India as you will get without actually going to India.

Why stay in Little India?

Many of Singaporeâ€™s best guesthouses and hostels are located here, making it a popular destination for budget travelers. There are also some excellent mid-range boutique hotels available here.

Little India is the place to stay if you are looking for cheap accommodation options and love eating delicious Indian food.

Whereas parts of Singapore can feel a bit â€œsterile,â€ Little India is an excellent place to stay if you want to escape the modern shopping malls and experience Singaporeâ€™s ethnic roots.

Little Indiaâ€™s two MRT stations (Little India Station and Rochor Station) also make it a convenient base from which to explore the rest of the city, only 15 min to the city center.

Things to See and Do in Little India

Tekka Centre

Explore the lively market stalls of Tekka Centre. If you are hungry, head to the ground floor. Here, you will find stalls selling vegetarian dishes from India, China, and Malaysia. There is also a wet market on the same floor, with many vegetables, seafood, and fruits.

Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple

Visit the colorful Hindu temple Sri Veeramakaliamman, one of Singaporeâ€™s oldest and most famous Hindu temples, constructed in 1881. There are several other temples in this area too.

Mustafa Centre

Little Indiaâ€™s landmark shopping center is old, packed, noisy, and unmissable.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

Little India can get extremely packed and noisy, especially on Sunday evenings when all the Indian foreign workers have their day off. Nightlife is quite limited and restaurants tend to close fairly early.

8. Sentosa Island

Sentosa Island is a favorite resort island just south of downtown Singapore. The island was once a British military fortress but was renamed â€œSentosaâ€ and handed over as a part of Singapore after World War II.

Sentosa means â€œtranquility and peaceâ€ in Malay. Its white tropical beaches and beautiful landscape make it easy to see why it was once named so.

However, these days, it is decidedly less peaceful. Developed as an entertainment center, the small island of Sentosa is packed with activities and experiences to keep you busy. There are two golf courses, a couple of Casinos, and several theme parks, including Universal Studios Singapore and SEA Aquarium. There are also boardwalk cafes, restaurants, and a 2 km-long human-made white sand beach. You will never have a dull moment at Sentosa!

You can quickly get to and from Sentosa with the cable car, the monorail Sentosa Express, or by walking over the nice pedestrian bridge (a 10 min walk), all from HarbourFront Station (purple North East Line and orange Circle Line).

Why stay on Sentosa Island?

If you want to combine Singaporeâ€™s big city sightseeing with some beach time, then Sentosa is the place to stay. The beach and all the entertainment offered here make Sentosa popular among families traveling with children, as well as golfers (Yep, there is a golf track here).

There are three beaches in Sentosa, each with its unique charm and character. Head to Siloso Beach for bustling restaurants and attractions. Palawan Beach is the place to head for kidsâ€™ playgrounds, parks, and a lagoon, and it is very popular among families with children. Tanjong Beach is ideal for those looking for more peace and quiet.

Sentosa Island has some top-notch luxury resorts, making it the perfect place for families with kids to stay. There are also a couple of fantastic high-end boutique hotels, like The Barracks Hotel, which is perfect for a romantic getaway .

And of course, there are Sentosâ€™s star attractions, Universal Studios, and the SEA Aquarium.

Things to see and do on Sentosa Island

Beaches

There are three beaches on Sentosa Island: Siloso Beach, Palawan Beach, and Tanjong Beach. Tanjong is the quietest and most peaceful, while Siloso is all about enjoying good food and drinks at the many restaurants, pubs, and cafes. Palawan, with its playgrounds, parks, and lagoon, is perfect for families with kids.

Universal Studios

Sentosa houses South East Asiaâ€™s only Universal Studios, Universal Studios Singapore. Here, you can visit one of the worldâ€™s most famous theme parks, which features mummies, dinosaurs, and the worldâ€™s tallest dueling roller coasters. Weâ€™ve been a couple of times and had a great time!

SEA Aquarium

Sentosa has one of the worldâ€™s largest aquariums, the SEA Aquarium. It houses over 100,000 sea animals and fish, and it is great fun for kids and adults!

Singapore Cable Car

Taking the Singapore Cable Car is the most fun way to get to Sentosa Island. We took this, and the view is breathtaking.

Megazip Line

If you are not scared of heights and want a thrilling experience, try the Megazip on Sentosa. The zip line is 450 m long and 75 m high.

Madame Tussauds Singapore

At Madame Tussauds Singapore on Sentosa, you can â€œmeetâ€ many celebrities, famous sports athletes, and film stars. If you are into Marvel (who isnâ€™t?), you can experience a cool 4D show of the Marvel universe. You can get up close here with Loki, Captain Marvel, Thor, Black Panther, Rocket, Spider-Man, Ant-Man, and the Wasp.

Sentosa Waterpark

Sentosa has a huge waterpark called Adventure Cove Waterpark. In addition to thrilling water slides and tunnels, you can meet dolphins and huge manta rays at the park.

Gogreen Eco Adventure Sentosa

At Sentosaâ€™s Gogreen ECO Adventure, you can rent bicycles or kick scooters to explore Sentosa Island. You can rent per hour, day, or overnight (24 hours).

Sentosa Golf Club

Sentosa Golf Club has two huge and beautiful golf courses â€“ Serapong and Tanjong. It was ranked in Golf Digest Worldâ€™s 100 Greatest Golf Courses 2022-23.

Casino

Sentosa has a casino as a part of the Resorts World Sentosa.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

Staying on Sentosa Island is not very convenient if youâ€™re in Singapore to explore the cityâ€™s sights and attractions. You canâ€™t exactly pop into your hotel room for rest between sightseeing excursions. But if you have the time, consider spending a night or two out here for beach time and visiting a theme park.

The island can sometimes feel like a colossal theme park. It can get quite busy on weekends and public holidays, with long queues and hefty waiting times, especially on public transport. The Island only has top-end resorts, with no budget or even mid-range accommodation options.

9. Katong / Joo Chiat

Katong is our last neighborhood in this guide, and itâ€™s not one that youâ€™ll see talked about a lot. It is a residential area where high-rise apartment buildings and modern condos stand alongside traditional Peranakan shophouses. While it may not be on most touristsâ€™ radar, it is a trendy area among expats and those who prefer staying in a neighborhood with more of a local feel.

Katongâ€™s main sight is the well-preserved Chinese shophouses along Joo Chiat and Kong Seng Road. These have become world-famous for their colorful facades and attract photographers from all over the world.

Katong also has quite the blossoming cafe scene, with new cool coffee shops and eateries popping up every time we visit.

The ever-popular East Coast Park stretches along the coastline and is a mecca for anyone who loves outdoor sports. We love to rent bikes and spend an afternoon riding along the coast before stopping at one of the many hawker centers for some delicious food.

There is a wakeboard waterpark, running trails, and plenty of room for playing ball or just having a picnic on the grass while watching the windsurfers do their thing. For kids, the Coastal Playgrove is very popular, with Singaporeâ€™s tallest outdoor play area and slide.

There is even a man-made beach, with breakwaters making it safe for swimming!

It is easy to see why Katongh has long been a favorite among expats, with its low-key residential feel, cozy cafes, and seaside park. In recent years, some excellent new hotels have also opened up. And with several new MRT stations, getting to and from the city center will become much faster.

Why Stay in Katong?

With the opening of the Thompson East-Coast MRT line and the new MRT stations drastically cutting down on transport time, using Katong as a base for exploring Singapore has become a more attractive option.

The neighborhood has a quieter, more residential feel than downtown Singapore, with excellent cafes and restaurants. Lastly, hotel prices are generally cheaper here than in more central parts of the city.

Walking distance to East Coast Park, with all it has to offer, means you can combine sightseeing with spending some time on the beach or relaxing by the seaside. It may be time to consider staying in Katong on your next Singapore visit!

Things to see and do in Katong

East Coast Park

This coastline park has a man-made beach, green lawns, a wakeboarding lake, bicycle rental shops, a childrenâ€™s play area, and several hawker food centers.

Beautiful Peranakan shophouses

Walk around Joo Chiat and admire some of Singaporeâ€™s best-preserved Peranakan-style architecture.

Parkway Parade

Parkway Parade has been an iconic neighborhood mall since 1984. It has plenty of eateries, supermarkets, and shops, including an excellent food court on the ground floor.

This cute and colorful little breakfast spot specializes in traditional Singapore breakfasts, such as Kaya toast with soft-boiled eggs.

Whatâ€™s the catch?

The new Katong MRT stations on the Thompson East Coast Line have not yet opened. If there are no further delays, they will open in June 2024.
